results.title: Intelligence
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Linda Jassim and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
How do you quantify differences in intelligence? How is intelligence determined? How can it be measured? Is it related to the brain? Can it ever be defined? Does heredity or experience define the upper limit of intelligence and what is the relationship between intelligence and motivation? These questions and the usefulness of intelligence tests are considered by a variety of psychologists.

results.title: The biology of behavior
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Steven Talley, David Stone and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Humans are quick thinking, quick acting animals. This ability to react is controlled by the nervous system, which in turn is controlled by a complex system of neurotransmitters in the brain. This program examines the operation of these neurotransmitters, their effect on individual personality and what happens when these networks break down due to neurotransmitter diseases, in particular, Parkinson’s Disease.

results.title: Issues in psychology
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, David Stone and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Psychology is a dynamic, diverse discipline concerned with the study of the human condition. What are the major issues in, and impact of, psychology today? To examine this question, a panel of US psychologists are assembled including psychobiologist, James McGaugh, social psychologist, Lee Ross, cognitive/social psychologist, Elizabeth Loftus, and Professor Joseph White, a developmental psychologist.

results.title: Conformity, obedience and dissent
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Leslie Hill and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Scientific experiments have consistently revealed how difficult it is for the individual to dissent or disobey within Western society. This video examines the psychological and social phenomena of conformity, obedience and dissent, using interviews with prominent US psychologists and referring to landmark experiments on obedience such as that conducted by Stanley Milgram. In this experiment, two-thirds of subjects applied increasingly powerful electric shocks as punishment simply because an authority figure told them to do so.

results.title: Psychology Today Series

results.title: Token economy: behavourism applied (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Elisabeth Hall, editor of Psychology Today, interviews the eminent Behaviourist, B.F. Skinner. Skinner explains, with examples, his theory of behaviour modification (“operant conditioning”) through positive and negative reinforcement. He cites the five classic examples of mistreatment, then explains the use of tokens in a program of reinforcement therapy. The director of the Adolf Meyer Centre explains how token economy is practised. Views all aspects of the Centre’s life and contrasts its extremely high success rate with the generally lower rehabilitation rate of traditional therapy. Also Bernard Wagner discusses the concept of “time out”.

results.title: Social psychology (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Joel Gold, James B. Lipscomb, Carole Hart and CRM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Discusses psychological concepts applicable to the social problems arising from the school bussing of black children to previously all white schools. Interesting juxtaposition between the integrated classroom, and interviews with those who are opposed to bussing black children to all white schools. Emphasises the skill of the classroom teacher in being aware of preserving a positive self-image among the black children.

results.title: Information processing (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Hart, Carole Hart and Communication Research Media Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Using for its base a crowded noisy cocktail party as observed from a control booth, analyses how people process information. Pretty girls and bizarrely dressed men demonstrate attention, language processing, long and short term memory, mnemonics, retrieval strategies, and problem solving.

results.title: The Sensory world (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Joel Gold, Tom Lazarus, Philip Mendlow and CRM Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”
Examines and demonstrates the empirical mechanics of human perception or misperception of our environments and the functioning - both normal and impaired - of the human senses. Uses animation to demonstrate various phenomena of the brain and illustrates its functions. Includes explanation of experiments with optic fibres and with electrical stimulation of the human brain and the memory.
Suitable for upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.
